title: Auckland New Zealand driver who was given a parking fine uses GPS to prove his innocence
text:
A driver was able to successfully prove his innocence using a GPS tracker after he was wrongly given a parking fine.

Dyllan Cochrane, 31, parked his car outside the Mt Wellington City Fitness gym in Auckland, New Zealand, on October 12.

Mr Cochrane said he entered the car park at 3.03pm and returned to his car later to find he had been given a ticket at 4.37pm for breaching the two-hour limit.

According to the ticket, Mr Cochrane had parked his car at 2.20pm.

New Zealand man Dyllan Cochrane was able to prove his innocence using a GPS tracker after he was wrongfully fined $65 by a parking warden while he was at the gym

'I was at the gym one day and me and my partner came out and all of a sudden we've got a ticket and it was for breaching a two-hour car park time,' he told Stuff.

'It's just unfair what is going on here, I'm here to get to the bottom of this.'

After taking his complaint directly to Wilson Parking he was told he had parked illegally.

Luckily for Mr Cochrane, he was able to use his car's GPS tracker which proved he was 6km away from the car park at 2.20pm.

CCTV of the car park also proved Mr Cochrane's innocence.

'It's frustrating, if I didn't have all this evidence they probably would have got away with this fine. It makes you wonder how many times they do get away with it,' Mr Cochrane said.

Mr Cochrane described the parking ticket system as 'prehistoric and chaotic'.

After showing evidence of his innocence Mr Cochrane said Wilson Parking waived his fine but he said it was disappointing it took to long for them to accept their error.
description: Dyllan Cochrane, 31, parked his car outside the Mt Wellington City Fitness gym in Auckland, New Zealand on October 12.
authors: Adam Mccleery For Daily Mail Australia
